embeds.title: Poltergeist
embeds.description:
Rare Power / 1 :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

Whenever you play an **Ethereal** card, a random enemy loses 6 (8) HP.

“Boring != bad”
its not bad but it is boring

Bolstering flame means that boring cards like this still serve a purpose
It's also not afterlife exclusive, seals, apparitions, and cards from other characters work
Going from afterlife only to ethereal was a huge buff
not being 2c anymore was also quite impt

By far the biggest thing that makes this card so much better than it was is how many afterlife cards were changed to be desirable to play. Before, it was correct to nearly always let all of them exhaust at the end of the turn to get free, full value. Now, you have a much more impactful choice, since allowing them to exhaust themselves only gives you partial value, and most of the afterlife card pool (especially certain key cards like sear, specter's wail, ghost shield, burning question, and hexaguard) often encourage you to play them for full value. Buffing the wheel also makes you want to play afterlife cards more often, since there are much better long term rewards for igniting all the flames, so you will naturally play afterlife cards more often to meet certain ghostflames requirements. It also helps that god of life was changed to be more meaningful in the final fight, and having a card like this that can help counteract the extra healing is useful. Making it work on any ethereal card is great to help broaden the pool of applicable cards to trigger this, and still feels very on theme for hexaghost. The cost reduction from 2 down to 1 is also much appreciated. In all honesty, it's shocking that poltergeist was able to be buffed this much without ended up as totally overpowered.

It feels a bit like spreading slime, a sort of sideways inflame that helps scale up your damage only on certain subset of cards. I'm usually happy with inflame when it's dealing at least 6+ damage a turn, and considering the active desire to have powers to trigger the bolstering ghostflame, you only really need to be able to play 1 ethereal card a turn for this to feel meaningful, though of course you'd like to trigger it more than that. You do have to consider that this is a rare, and thus has an opportunity cost that spreading slime and inflame don't. I still don't think I'm thrilled to take this from a boss reward, and I would need a very ethereal heavy deck to buy it at a store.

However, I do think I would usually take it from building up rare chance, and at least it's net positive most of the time when you pick it from a boss reward. I do think this could be moved down to uncommon if we want to free up space at rare, as the effect of conditional, linear damage scaling doesn't feel all that  rare worthy. Hexaghost can currently scale their damage up fairly well through strength or intensity as well, both of which are represented at uncommon and also only work with a specific subset of cards/interactions. Not a ton of relic synergies outside of the obvious ones (mummified hand, bird-faced urn, bolster rod). Gifts from beyond is a great support piece for it to get more damage every turn. Upgrade is solid, and worth pursuing as long as you can play 2 or more ethereal cards per turn to make it a +4 consistently.
seems fine?
Spreading slime is a bit more meta than poltergeist since licks REALLY need the damage into god of life, where it's wayore important than equivalent strength.

Also, it's funny how poltergeist went through three or so iterations before we came back to the original design lol. Poltergeist itself wasn't really buffed that much, but it's surroundings changed that the original concept became good again.

Slime is definitely a more critical supportive card, especially because there are more ways to spam/recur multiple goop sources over a turn, and a few ways to multiply the value of goop or let it not get consumed on the first hit. If anything, I would say that's more evidence to put poltergeist down at uncommon. The major thing that makes it feel so much better than it used to is that the thing it asks you to do (spend energy playing your afterlife/ethereal cards) is much more rewarding than it used to be.
